title: $STZ Constellation Brands Q4 2025 Earnings Conference Call

rawLines.text: Greetings and welcome to the
Constellation Brands Q4 fiscal year 2025
earnings call. At this time, all
participants are listening mode. If
anyone should require operator
assistance, please press star zero on
your telephone keypad. A question and
answer session will follow the formal
presentation. You may be placed into
question queue at any time by pressing
star one. And we ask you please limit
yourselves to one question, then return
to the queue. As a reminder, this
conference is being recorded. It's now
my pleasure to turn the call over to
your host, Joseph Suarez, vice president
investor relations. Please go ahead,
sir.
Thank you, Kevin. Good morning all and
welcome to Constellation Brands Q4 and
fullyear fiscal 25 conference call. I'm
here this morning with Bill Nulans, our
CEO, and Gar Henson, our CFO. We trust
that you had the opportunity to review
the news release, CEO and CFO commentary
and accompanying slides made available
yesterday evening in the investor
section of our company's website
www.cbrands.com. As we have received a
couple questions regarding certain
figures contained in our slides, please
note that we expect our beer net sales
growth rate for fiscal 26 to be between
0 to 3% and for fiscal 27 and 28 to be 2
to 4%. And our operating income growth
rate for fiscal 26 is expected to be
between 02%. And for fiscal 27 to 28, we
expect operating margins to be
approximately 39 to 40%. On that note,
as a reminder, reconciliations between
the most directly comparable gap
measures and non-GAAP financial measures
discussed on this call are included in
the news release and website. And we
encourage you to also refer to the news
release and consolations SEC filings for
risk factors that may impact
forward-looking statements made on this
call. Before turning the call over to
Bill and Guard, please keep in mind that
as usual, answers provided today will be
referencing comparable results unless
otherwise specified and that any
references to expectations for fiscal 26
to fiscal 28 reflect the anticipated
impact of the tariffs announced by the
US government on April 2nd and the
Canadian government on March 4th of this
year, inclusive of the delay in the
effectiveness of certain tariffs
announced by the US government
yesterday, which will particularly
impact the wine spirits business.
Lastly, in line with prior quarters, I
would ask that you limit yourselves to
one question per person, which will help
us to end our call on time. Thanks in
advance. And now, here is Bill. Thanks,
Joe, and welcome everyone to our Q4 and
fullyear fiscal 25 call. As usual, I
will outline a few overarching
highlights, but we will then move
immediately to Q&A as our broader
commentary was provided to you
yesterday. So, let's get going. In a
tough socioeconomic environment, we are
taking decisive actions designed to
continue to support our industry-leading
beer business, reset our cost base, and
redefine our
portfolio. More specifically, first in
fiscal 25, despite a softer consumer
demand backdrop largely driven by what
we believe to be nonstructural
socioeconomic factors, we continue to
deliver enterprise net sales growth,
realize substantial comparable operating
margin improvement, and achieve
doubledigit comparable EPS growth.
Second, looking ahead, while we expect
these nonstructural socioeconomic
factors affecting consumer demand to
gradually stabilize and subside, we
remain focused on driving distribution
gains, on launching disciplined
innovation, and on deploying incremental
marketing investments to support the
growth of our beer business, all while
continuing to deliver best-in-class
operating margins. Third, in addition,
we expect significant improvements in
the performance of our wine and spirits
business beyond fiscal
26 following the anticipated closing of
the 2025 wine deficit transaction that
is primarily centered around the sale of
the remaining mainstream wine brands in
that portfolio as well as the
implementation of associated
restructuring actions expected to yield
over 200 million in net annualized cost
savings across the enterprise by fiscal
Fourth, against that backdrop, we are
targeting to deliver approximately 9
billion in operating cash flow from
fiscal 26 to 28 and approximately 6
billion in free cash flow as we continue
to invest primarily in the modular
development of our third brewery in
Veraracruz and modular additions at our
existing facilities in Mexico. And
fifth, in line with this strong cash
flow generation and having achieved our
comparable net leverage ratio target in
fiscal 25, we remain committed to a
disciplined and balanced capital
deployment framework, including our 30%
dividend payout ratio and executing
share repurchases against our new
three-year $4 billion authorization. And
with that, G and I will be happy to take
your questions.
Thank you. We'll now be conducting a
question and answer session. If you'd
like to be placed in the question queue,
please press star one on your telephone
keypad. And as a reminder, please ask
one question, then return to the queue.
Our first question is coming from Lauren
Lieberman from Barclay Laser Line is now
live. Hi, great. Uh good morning and
thanks a lot for the question. Um I
wanted to know if you could comment more
specifically on tariffs. um you know are
is the Bureau of Business currently
USMCA certified so we can get some
visibility on what is baked in in terms
of tariffs um with regard to Mexico um
and also what are what else is baked in
in terms of um aluminum cans and so on.
So more visibility um there would be
really helpful and then was also just
curious on that on the longer term
forecast um around beer and the notion
you know socioeconomic non-structural
dynamics but how are you thinking about
beer industry growth over this
projection um timeline. Thanks.
Sure. Why don't I start with the uh
first part of the question? We have been
USMCA compliant uh since it was
implemented uh several years ago and
remain USMCA compliant today. Uh in
addition to that, Lauren, uh the the
guidance that we provided uh does
include the impact for all tariffs
announced by the US government on April
2nd and by the Canadian government on
March 4th. For our beer business, this
includes the impact on our aluminum
cans. And for our Y business, this
includes the impact for our brands
coming out of New Zealand and Italy into
the US and for our brands uh from the US
into
Canada. Relative to the longer range uh
perspective on beer, there's been
obviously a lot of what we see as
near-term headwinds. Uh but we think
that those over time, particularly as
the Hispanic consumer who's been
particularly challenged, uh gets back to
more uh sort of normal operating
procedure.
Thank you. Next question is coming from
Nick Modi from RBC Capital Markets. Your
line is now live.
Yeah, thank you. Good morning, everyone.
Um Bill, maybe if I could just kind of
uh piggy back off Lauren's question on
the long-term beer outlook. You know, I
I get the fact that things are really,
you know, kind of choppy right now, but
the but the cut in the in the guide just
kind of over the next couple years
seemed a bit extreme relative to what
you guys have been doing, even with the
slowing down that we've been seeing that
I think we can all agree some of it is
very temporary. So, you know, when I
speak to the trade, it's pretty clear
nothing has really changed on an
underlying basis with the the brands,
the momentum, kind of how retailers are
uh looking to space your portfolio in a
in a in a bigger sense, greater manner.
So just wanted to kind of get your
philosophy on on the range of being down
you know this up two to four which is
you know versus the seven to nine and
kind of how you're thinking about that.
I mean are you just kind of assuming
things just stay the way they are and
and you know if there's upside great. Um
so any context on that would be really
really helpful. Sure. Well let's start
with the most important thing Nick and
uh today's Nick's birthday so happy
birthday Nick. Now getting on to the
main point. Um the most important thing
as as we look at it relative to the the
medium term is our brand health. Um and
fortunately all of our brand health
metrics remain extremely strong. Um
we're very focused on what we can
control and that's distribution. It's
focused innovation. It's making sure
that our execution is is top-notch. uh
you noted we gained over uh 10% in share
uh of space uh in the resets that
occurred last year. So that remains a
positive factor. It's very difficult to
know exactly how long some of these
socioeconomic issues are going to uh
continue. Uh certainly we know from that
the Hispanic consumer is particularly
concerned about a number of issues. Um
and we would certainly expect some
improvement as those consumers become
more comfortable u and less concerned
about the many issues that follow them.
Um we don't have an exact answer to when
that is going to moderate. uh and I
think it's important to note that uh the
the guidance that we have provided
reflects the fact that there are a lot
of unknowns today many including things
like tariffs but also the impact that
that's we're seeing with the Hispanic
consumer. Um until we get a more
definitive uh answer to some of those
questions it's a tough answer to give.
Fortunately, that consumer, the Hispanic
consumer, continues to show
extraordinarily loyalty uh to our brands
and over the long term that will
moderate and continue to allow us to
gain share as we have for the last
several
years. And uh Nick, uh let me just add a
couple of of the actual brand health
stats that uh that Bill referenced.
We've actually seen some pretty
significant increases in aided awareness
and consideration for Medel, Corona, and
Pacificico, which is in line with what
we would expect from the media
investment uh that we put in place this
last year. All brands are holding steady
on measures of of popularity across all
adults, Hispanic, and Gen Z. Uh
Pacificico was up statistically
significantly in California. And all our
brands are holding steady on the other
metrics that we track, including is this
a brand I love? Is it a brand everyone
likes? Is it a good value? Is it a brand
with heritage and net favorability?
Thank you. Next question is coming from
Bonnie Herszog from Goldman Sachs. Your
line is now live. All right. Thank you.
Good morning. I just wanted to ask a
quick followup on, you know, in the
context of your cut to your medium-term
algo. What are you assuming for the beer
category growth or I guess declines over
the next few years? And then I wanted to
ask about margins, beer margins. you
know, could you maybe walk through the
different puts and takes that are going
to allow you to deliver your
best-in-class beer margins of 39 to 40%
over the next few years despite, I
guess, a considerable expected slowdown
in volume and and some tariff risk. I
mean, you mentioned some cost cutting.
So, could you give us some more color on
that and and possibly quantify? Thank
you.
Um I think uh slide 18 is going to help
you uh on some of those uh broad
answers. But our view is over the course
of the medium term the beer industry
overall will likely go back to what it
has done over the last several years
which is roughly flat to down two
somewhere in that range. Um and as we've
said on prior calls, uh we've seen a
significant delta between whatever the
beer industry is and our performance
against it where we have gained
significant share. Um we expect that
that overall approach is going to
continue um and that we'll get back to a
more normal I'll call it normal
trajectory uh into the medium term. as I
spoke on a couple of the prior
questions, u how quickly that comes
around will largely depend on what
consumer sentiment is as we move
forward. Yeah. And then, you know,
Bonnie, on margins, uh I apologize, this
is probably a bit of a boring story
because I think we've said it, you know,
a few times before. Nothing's really
changed. Um first of all, we're going to
manage our our footprint in and the
modular fashion that we've referenced
previously. So, we're going to limit the
impact of depreciation and and uh
overhead absorption issues. Uh in
addition to that uh we'll have
incremental volume growth. We'll uh
maintain our 1 to 2% pricing algorithm
and uh certainly we'll we'll continue to
uh on with our uh uh our cost savings
initiatives. Obviously those uh
tailwinds will be offset on a
year-to-year basis by inflation uh and
and tariffs, but net net um you know we
put all that together we think we can
continue to deliver best-in-class
margins at 39 to 40%.
Thank you. Next question is coming from
Rob Botenstein from Evercore ISI. Your
line is now live.
Great. Thank you very much. Um I just
want to make sure you know why I I get
this as as crystal clear as possible. Um
I'm wondering if you can just kind of go
through again how you're thinking about
um free cash flow deployment and you
know given the fact that you know you've
you've you've shrunk the wine and
spirits business or re repositioned it
uh and given the fact that at least over
the next couple of years um you know you
expect less growth from the beer side of
the business you're reducing
capex. Um are you today and and kind of
going forward uh more open to larger
acquisitions? Are you spending more time
on acquisitions given the increased cash
flow? Uh so love to get your thoughts on
that. Uh I know you've re-uped the
authorization on the share buyback.
um you know is tied to that is is that
you know a strong commitment that uh you
will buy back I think it was $4 billion
worth of stock over the next three years
just trying to get a sense of the
priorities there and what is kind of
guidance versus actual uh commitments
along those lines. Thank you.
Well, thanks for the question, Robert.
And, you know, on the one hand, this
will be another boring answer because I
think it's a lot of consistency with
what we've said in the past, but
actually, I think it's pretty exciting
what we're going to be doing here. I
mean, as we outlined, um, through FY208,
we're going to generate $9 billion of
operating cash flow and $6 billion of
free cash flow. Um, our our capital
allocation priorities don't change. Uh,
we're we're uh we're committed to being
uh we're committed to achieving three
times leverage. We're we're there now.
We're actually a little bit below there
now. We're committed to returning um
capital to shareholders through
dividends and we'll maintain our our
approximately 30% dividend payout as we
go forward. And then you referenced the
new authorization for $4 billion in
share purchases uh that we received from
our board um yesterday. Uh this is
actually I think very exciting. I mean,
not only is the $4 billion share of
purchase authorization reflective of our
discipline around capital allocation and
share of purchases more specifically,
but it's also reflective of the fact
that, you know, we think that we're
undervalued. our share price is
undervalued, remains undervalued, and
we're going to uh we're going to execute
on that share authorization as we have
uh this past uh this past fiscal year
where we'll be disciplined on a
quarter-to- quarter basis, but we will
also have the ability to be
opportunistic as we see uh dislocations
in our share price. And then as we round
out capital allocation, you know, we're
going to continue to invest in our beer
business as we outlined in the materials
yesterday, uh $2 billion uh over the
next few years. and u you know M&A
remains the last of our um the last of
our priorities mainly around smaller
plug-in uh opportunities.
Thank you. Next question is coming from
Chris Carrier from Wells Fargo
Securities. Your line is now live.
Hi, good morning everyone.
Hey Chris. So,
um, Gar, can can you just talk about the
main drivers and
considerations for gross margins going
into fiscal 26? I fully appreciate that
you had a lot of detail in the in the
slides, but I'm really trying to parse
out the impact of, you know, tariffs on
this model, whether that's just the
aluminum cans relative to everything
else. you also perhaps have a quite a
notable currency tailwind in fiscal 26
that may not help you in go forward
years. And so I'm really just trying to
understand, you know, the puts and
takes, specifically the impact of
tariffs relative to everything else on
the model in fiscal 26 and whether there
are some nuances like currency that
won't repeat so that we can have a
better idea of how to um layer this in,
you know, going into fiscal 27 and and
fiscal 28.
Yeah. So look, let me do my best there,
Chris, and if we need to follow up, we
can follow up. you know, as you know,
the the guidance that we provided
yesterday, as we said, you know, in
includes the impact of tariffs for our
beer business. That is the impact uh on
on aluminum cans. As it relates to
currency, you know, as you know, we've
talked about this, you know, multiple
times that, you know, we have a
multi-year layered approach to how we
manage our currency. as we entered in
FY26,
uh we're above 70% uh hedged and we've
seen some actually dislocations uh in uh
in the in the US peso rate here.
Shouldn't say some dislocations, but
some weakness and we've taken
opportunities to lighter in some
incremental uh hedges both for for this
year and future years. So, as always, we
look to sort of
uh we look to manage that on a
year-to-year basis so that the impact
isn't uh you know, isn't that u that
material from a year-to-year
perspective. We try to smooth that uh as
best we can.
Thank you. Next question today is coming
from Nadine Sarwat from Burn Senior.
Line is now live.
Thank you guys and appreciate all the
incremental color that was provided in
the prepared remarks in the
presentation. Two questions for me. You
called out a tough socioeconomic
environment in your prepared remarks.
Can you explain exactly what you're
assuming in terms of that socioeconomic
environment for the next three years?
Are you assuming the current situation
remains status quo or you baking in some
improvement in the back of that? And
then secondly on the weak depletion
numbers and especially Melo appreciate
the commentary that you provided. Could
you pull apart the factors onto what's
driving that maybe what has changed in a
little more detail? I don't know if a
rank order of magnitude or trying to
quantify these in any way possible and
maybe you have any incremental consumer
insight on consumer type pack type
channel any incremental color would be
helpful. Thank you.
Sure. Um, so let's let's talk first
about the Hispanic consumer because I
think this is an important element. We
we do, as you would expect, we do a fair
amount of cons research around this
consumer given that they represent
roughly 50% of our overall beer
business. And the fact is a lot of
consumers in the Hispanic community are
concerned right now. U twothirds of them
are concerned about higher prices on
things like food, gas, and other
essentials. Over half are concerned
relative to immigration issues and how
those impact. A number of them are
concerned about job losses in industries
that have a high uh Latino employment
base. And what does that do? That has
tended to mean that the consumer has
pulled back on spending on a number of
categories. The single biggest one,
interestingly, is restaurants. Um, but a
lot of other consumer goods, clothing,
home choice things to do. Uh, travel.
Beer's quite a ways down the list, but
it's certainly on the list because
things like social gatherings, an area
where the Hispanic consumer often
consumes beer, are declining today as
part of these overarching concerns that
they have. Therefore, um, you know, all
of that has had impact uh, on our
business. As you know, Medel is over 50%
Hispanic in terms of its demographic
base. So, this decline in uh efforts to
go to restaurants, to have social
gatherings, things that are very much
beer occasions have softened uh in in
the more recent term. And it's going to
be key to watch as to how that uh impact
continues or doesn't continue as we go
forward. net net. It's nonstructural. Uh
this is not our our brands and our brand
health continues to be top-notch. We
continue to focus on what we can win at
winning the shelf, winning execution,
continuing to bring interesting
innovation to the table that allows us
to continue to outperform the overall
category. But like as you would expect,
we're we we're going to need want to see
some improvement in the consumer brand
health before we're able to correctly
project uh how long some of these
challenges are going to last. Gar,
anything you want to add? Yeah, just on
on some of the macro data points and
I'll give you sort of how we're thinking
about that for the forecast period that
we provided details on last night.
Um you know, we're not expecting any
material improvement over this forecast
period. you know, some of the macro
trends that we're seeing and that we're
tracking are are unemployment. And
obviously unemployment has started to
stabilize uh you know, across the board,
but we have seen weakness in those 4,000
calorie uh job sectors that have a
higher impact on beer uh beer
consumption. Uh year year-over-year real
disposable personal income uh reached a
two-year low in January and stayed low
uh in February. consumer sentiment uh
sentiment rather had reached a two and a
half year low in March. Uh and long-term
expectations from consumers isn't
expected to to change anytime soon. Um
you know, we've we've seen un uh
inflation rather uh the the expectations
for for um inflation uh to not get as uh
uh uh to not rebound quite as quickly as
we had as we had expected. And the
outlook for GDP growth now is a little
bit more muted uh than it was. So we're
not expecting any big improvements in
that as we go through calendar year 20
uh 25 we may see some of that moderate a
bit uh and into 26. So maybe some
marginal improvement but uh for the
forecast period we're not expecting any
material improvement in the the
macroeconomic conditions.
Thank you. Next question today's coming
from Peter Grom from UBS. Your line is
now live.
Thanks operator. Good morning everyone.
So I I was hoping to to talk more
near-term and just kind of get some
perspective and just in terms of what's
happening in terms of B or topline
growth currently, you know, obviously a
challenging, you know, exit rate and the
guidance does seem to imply some
improvement from that exit rate. So can
you maybe just help us frame how we
should be thinking about the guidance um
from here? Any considerations that we
should consider as it relates to to one
Q um and then just any thoughts in terms
of what we should anticipate price
versus volume. Thanks.
Well, I think if you'll recall from last
year, the strongest quarter uh that we
had and frankly that the industry had
was our fiscal Q1. Uh so while while we
don't make any habit as you know of
giving quarterly guidance uh certainly
the biggest uh uh overlap that we have
is in this very first quarter as the
business uh started to soften for the
industry as well as for us uh as you
progressed through the back half of last
year. So, um, you know, that when when
you combine that with some of the, uh,
socioeconomic climate issues that I've
already referred to, u, I think you're
going to see some volatility as the year
goes on. You know, again, the the key
thing for us, I I know I'm repeating
myself, but I think it's important to
recognize our brand health remains best
of class, and in the longer run, that
will continue to pay dividends uh for us
as consumers get back to a normalized
behavioral pattern.
Thank you. Next question is coming from
Bill Kirk from Roth MKM. Your line is
now live.
Uh good morning. Um, so some people
including the Teamsters and maybe one of
the mega brewers, uh, they seem to be
trying to drive a wedge between American
beer and imported beer. Are they having
any success with that in the eyes of
consumers? And and how much influence do
you think those type of groups have over
alcohol tariff policies?
It's interesting question, Bill. Uh,
tough to answer some of that question.
What what I would say is, you know, one
of the things that we're proud of as a
company is our 80 years as an American
company. Um, as you know, we're our
ownership is entirely in this country,
although we make most of our beer in
Mexico because we have Mexican heritage
brands, but we spend roughly a billion
dollars a year in the United States
market supporting our brands. Uh we have
uh many of our grains uh and our
barley's and our corn grown in the
mountain west of the United States uh
for inputs. Um I think uh you know when
the overall teamsters take a very hard
look that our we are very uh supportive
of the teamsters. I think we have
brought more jobs to this marketplace
than any other competitor has because of
the growth of our business over time uh
through our distributor network. So u I
I think as people take a real hard look
at what our company is and how we have
performed in the marketplace uh they
will recognize that we have done an
exceptional job of building US jobs as
we've also built our business in Mexico
to support those US jobs.
Thank you. And next question is coming
from Andrew Schelse from Capital
Market. Your line is now live.
Hey, good morning. Thanks for taking the
questions. Um, you know, appreciate all
the detail on the guidance. Obviously,
it's a very fluid environment. I guess
when you just think through all the
assumptions that you've made here over
the next in recasting kind of the next
three years, where do you think there's
the biggest risks to your assumptions
and the biggest maybe where we might
look back and say, hey, you know, that
that turned out to be a little bit
conservative.
Yeah, I think the single biggest risk
that that we have is is where the
consumer is and how long their concerns
last. Um, you know, if we had a crystal
ball on that, be a lot easier to make
some projections. Uh, because, you know,
as the consumer feels better about
things, that will help not only our
business, but the overall category.
Believe me, we'd like to see a healthy
category. That would be to everyone in
our industry's benefit. And we certainly
always like to see the industry succeed
as we succeed. So, um, that that's the
biggest variable that I think is out
there is, you know, when when does the
consumer come around? We're going to
stay crystal clear focused on the
variables that we can control, as I've
talked to earlier today. Um, but the,
you know, the consumer sentiment and the
consumer's desire to get back out and
shop and be comfortable in the
socioeconomic environment is probably
the single biggest variable. It's tough
to predict.
Thank you. Next question today is coming
from General Pascelli from Needam and
Company. Your line is now live. Great.
Thanks. Thanks very much for the
question. Um I just had a housekeeping
item um on the wine business. So the the
$41 million impact that you called out
in your um your
commentary. Can you provide um some
detail on when you expect that to hit
the operating income? Is that going to
be in the first quarter of 2026? I guess
that's that's my first question. Just
any any color on the cadence. And then
as we think about the cost savings, I
think a hundred of the 200 million is
coming out of wine. Um is that going to
be more pronounced a more pronounced
benefit to the operating income looking
like if we had to look to 2027 or 2028,
is that going to be more of a a benefit
when we get to 2027? So again, any any
color on the cadence there I think would
be helpful. Thank you.
Yeah. So, uh, you know, the the $41
million that you referenced, uh, uh,
that was called out in the in the
prepared, uh, materials, that'll kind of
happen throughout the year. Uh, uh, so
just it won't be any one big quarter
where that hits, but throughout the
year. Uh, and then in terms of the cost
savings, and we called this out in our
materials, right? So, it's it's about
$100 million in total for wine and
spirits. We're expecting about $55
million in Q are are in fiscal 26. So
the the the majority of the actions that
we will take uh to achieve that $und00
million savings will occur in FY26. Uh
it's just you won't get the full run
rate of that u you know until until you
move into FY27 and then maybe a little
bit uh into FY28.
Thank you. Next question is coming from
Dar Mosinian from Morgan Stanley. Your
line is now live.
Hey, good morning. So, um, clearly a
pretty big revision in long-term beer
sales growth from the 7 to9 range to to
2 to 4 in fiscal 27 and 28. So, can you
just give us a little more detail on how
much of that is just related to the
external environment and more
conservatism on macros? How much of it
is pressure points maybe that are more
durable on the beer category, health and
wellness, demographics, etc. A and then
a third bucket of market share
opportunity for STZ. Just give us a
sense of conceptually, you know, how
much of that falls into each bucket. And
I realize this is like the eighth
version of this question you've gotten
on the call, but I I guess the point is
we're kind of hearing from you guys.
Your tone is that the beer depions
slowdown. It's more driven by short-term
factors. Obviously, we understand the
difficult macro environment, but at the
same time, you're making pretty large
revisions. the beer sales growth post
fiscal 26 which should be significantly
macro depressed based on what we're
seeing. So I'm just trying to sort of
bridge those two points and how you guys
think about that conceptually if that
makes sense. Yeah, it it it totally
does. Darl, um I our points are we have
a nearterm uh issue as it relates to
consumer sentiment. Um very difficult to
